para.paratext: Since the United States Supreme Court extended the confrontation clause to the states in Pointer v. Texas,[1] state courts have struggled with the issue of admitting hearsay in criminal cases. In 2004, the court redefined the approach for admitting hearsay in criminal cases in Crawford v. Washington[2] by holding that out of court “testimonial statements” by declarants who are unavailable at trial are inadmissible against criminal defendants who did not have a prior opportunity to cross examine the witnesses regardless of whether the statements are deemed reliable by a court. This rule is a distinct departure from previous cases permitting the admission of hearsay testimony in criminal trials.[3] Under Crawford, it is irrelevant whether the statement qualifies for admission under a recognized hearsay exception.[4]

Statements made to police officers are testimonial when the circumstances objectively indicate that there is no ongoing emergency, and that the purpose of the interrogation is to establish or prove events potentially relevant to a later criminal investigation. They are non-testimonial when made in the course of a police investigation under circumstances objectively indicating that the primary objective of the interrogation is to enable police to assist in an ongoing emergency. In Michigan v. Bryant,[5] the U.S. Supreme Court further expanded the framework for analyzing testimonial or non-testimonial statements. While the goal is still to discern the primary purpose of the statements, now there is also an objective evaluation of the circumstances regarding the interrogation and the actions of the participants.

Note that the erroneous admission of a witness's hearsay does not necessarily require reversal. In a criminal case, it is reversible error only if it appears likely that the hearsay contributed to the guilty verdict.[6] Thus, when the hearsay testimony is merely cumulative and when it is highly probable that its admission did not contribute to the guilty verdict, its admission into evidence will not warrant a new trial.[7]

The rule is clearly limited to statements which are “testimonial.” Admission of nontestimonial hearsay does not violate the Confrontation Clause.[8] The United States Supreme Court defined “testimonial” statements as those which are “made under circumstances which would lead an objective witness reasonably to believe that the statement would be available for use at a later trial.”[9] Testimonial statements include prior formal testimony, police interrogations,[10] police interviews of witnesses,[11] and “similar pretrial statements that declarants would reasonably expect to be used prosecutorially.”[12] Statements made to police officers without premeditation or afterthought or in the height of an emergency are not testimonial.[13]

In Pitts v. State,[14] the Georgia Supreme Court held that statements made during a 911 phone call in which the victim told the operator that she needed immediate assistance from the police because the defendant had broken into her home, was running around the house without any clothes on, and was violating his parole by being in the house were nontestimonial. The court explained that, if the primary purpose of an out-of-court statement “is to establish evidentiary facts, so that an objective person would recognize that the statement would be used in a future prosecution, then that [statement] ‘bears testimony’ against the accused and implicates the concerns of the Confrontation Clause.”[15]

On the other hand, if the primary purpose of a statement is “to avert a crime in progress or to seek assistance in a situation involving immediate danger,” it is not testimonial.[16] However, the Court in Pitts did caution that “in certain circumstances a caller may shift from a non-testimonial statement into a testimonial one.”[17] “When Amy Pitts explained to the operator that her husband had violated his parole and that he was ‘wanted,’ she came close to providing testimonial evidence.”[18] Determining whether a statement is testimonial will turn upon the circumstances at the time the statement is made.[19] Testimonial statements may need to be redacted for nontestimonial statements to be admissible.[20]

Generally, statements made to family members and friends are nontestimonial.[21] As noted by the Georgia Supreme Court, an “off-hand, overheard remark” or “a casual remark to an acquaintance” would not normally be considered testimonial.[22] In Turner v. State,[23] the court held that such statements, although made to police officer coworkers, were not testimonial in nature because the statements were “made in conversations with friends, before the commission of any crime, and without any reasonable expectation that they would be used at a later trial.”[24]

The Confrontation Clause will not constrain the use of a declarant's prior testimonial statements during his cross-examination at trial.[25] If former testimony is offered for some use other than to prove the truth of the matter asserted, confrontation issues are not implicated.
The use of a criminal indictment in an unrelated case is impermissible hearsay, as an indictment is simply a formal written accusation of a crime.[26]
Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. 36, 124 S. Ct. 1354, 158 L. Ed. 2d 177, 63 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1077 (2004).

See Ohio v. Roberts, 448 U.S. 56, 100 S. Ct. 2531, 65 L. Ed. 2d 597, 7 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1 (1980). In Ohio v. Roberts, the U.S. Supreme Court revisited the confrontation issue and clarified that admission of hearsay testimony in a criminal trial will not violate the Confrontation Clause if the declarant is deemed “unavailable” at trial and the testimony is found to have sufficient “indicia of reliability” The Court explained: “When a hearsay declarant is not present for cross-examination at trial, the Confrontation Clause normally requires a showing that he is unavailable. Even then, his statement is admissible only if it bears adequate ‘indicia of reliability.’ Reliability can be inferred without more in a case where the evidence falls within a firmly rooted hearsay exception. In other cases, the evidence must be excluded, at least absent a showing of particularized guarantees of trustworthiness.” Ohio v. Roberts, 448 U.S. 56, 100 S. Ct. 2531, 65 L. Ed. 2d 597, 7 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1 (1980). However, this ruling is no longer good law; thus, a mere finding of reliability of the out-of-court statement is not sufficient to justify its admission.
See Willingham v. State, 279 Ga. 886, 622 S.E.2d 343 (2005).
Michigan v. Bryant, 562 U.S. 344, 131 S. Ct. 1143, 179 L. Ed. 2d 93, 84 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1033 (2011).
Johnson v. State, 328 Ga. App. 702, 760 S.E.2d 682 (2014).
Marshall v. State, 297 Ga. 445, 774 S.E.2d 675 (2015).

Davis v. Washington, 547 U.S. 813, 126 S. Ct. 2266, 165 L. Ed. 2d 224, 70 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 472, 30 A.L.R.6th 599 (2006); Whorton v. Bockting, 549 U.S. 406, 127 S. Ct. 1173, 1183, 167 L. Ed. 2d 1, 72 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 635, 44 A.L.R. Fed. 2d 777 (2007).
Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. 36, 52, 124 S. Ct. 1354, 158 L. Ed. 2d 177, 63 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1077 (2004).
Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. 36, 124 S. Ct. 1354, 158 L. Ed. 2d 177, 63 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1077 (2004).

See, e.g., Lindsey v. State, 282 Ga. 447, 651 S.E.2d 66 (2007) (victim's statement, regarding hostilities between the victim and defendant, made to district attorney prosecuting a prior case was testimonial, and because the victim was unavailable, should have been excluded); Moody v. State, 277 Ga. 676, 594 S.E.2d 350 (2004) (victim's statement to police officer shortly after the defendant allegedly shot into the victim's bedroom while she was sleeping was type of “field interrogation” encompassed by Crawford); Jenkins v. State, 278 Ga. 598, 604 S.E.2d 789 (2004) (error to admit statements by defendant's uncle to police investigators regarding murder investigation); Singleton v. State, 326 Ga. App. 609, 757 S.E.2d 211 (2014).
Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. 36, 51, 124 S. Ct. 1354, 158 L. Ed. 2d 177, 63 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1077 (2004).

Davis v. Washington, 547 U.S. 813, 126 S. Ct. 2266, 165 L. Ed. 2d 224, 70 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 472, 30 A.L.R.6th 599 (2006); Pitts v. State, 280 Ga. 288, 627 S.E.2d 17 (2006). See also, e.g., Hester v. State, 283 Ga. 367, 659 S.E.2d 600 (2008) (statements made by victim to paramedic and police officer were for the purpose of diagnosis and treatment; the police activity in procuring the statements was minimal; there was no indication that the statements were intended for future prosecution); Williams v. State, 292 Ga. App. 892, 666 S.E.2d 18 (2008) (where bystanders shouted to police pursuing the defendant that the defendant had dropped something, statements were not testimonial because the police did not elicit the statements and the primary purpose in making the statements was to avert the crime in progress rather than to establish facts and events for a prosecution).
See also Davis v. Washington, 547 U.S. 813, 126 S. Ct. 2266, 165 L. Ed. 2d 224, 70 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 472, 30 A.L.R.6th 599 (2006) (reaching the same result on similar facts).

Statements that were made by bystanders during 911 calls regarding a shooting of victim were nontestimonial. The calls were made while the incident was still ongoing and the perpetrator was at large, and the nature of the operator's questions were designed to assist the police in meeting an ongoing emergency. Glover v. State, 285 Ga. 461, 678 S.E.2d 476 (2009).

Statements by a victim to neighbors, paramedics, and deputy as to identity of his shooter were nontestimonial. The victim was speaking about events as they were actually happening, and the primary purpose of the questioning was to enable police assistance to meet an ongoing emergency. Thomas v. State, 284 Ga. 540, 668 S.E.2d 711 (2008).

See Key v. State, 289 Ga. App. 317, 657 S.E.2d 273 (2008) (holding that statement were nontestimonial where the primary purpose of the 911 call was to prevent immediate harm to the public); Thompson v. State, 291 Ga. App. 355, 358, 662 S.E.2d 135 (2008) (holding that statements were nontestimonial “[i]n light of the caller's immediate need for medical attention and the proximity in time between the call and the attack”).

See also Davis v. Washington, 547 U.S. 813, 126 S. Ct. 2266, 165 L. Ed. 2d 224, 70 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 472, 30 A.L.R.6th 599 (2006) (suggesting that in some cases testimonial statements may need to be redacted).
Davis v. Washington, 547 U.S. 813, 126 S. Ct. 2266, 165 L. Ed. 2d 224, 70 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 472, 30 A.L.R.6th 599 (2006).

See, e.g., Gonzalez v. State, 277 Ga. App. 362, 626 S.E.2d 569 (2006) (statements to friend of the victim were not testimonial because they were not made to the police and they were not made in a setting where the declarant would reasonably believe the statements would later be used at trial); In re S.S., 281 Ga. App. 781, 637 S.E.2d 151 (2006) (statements by molestation victim to her mother and sister were properly admissible).
